title: My Weird Winter Skin Thing and the Pear Tallow Balm That Fixed It
body:
Look, it’s February. My radiator sounds like a dying robot and my face feels like old paper. I was just sitting there, you know, scrolling, and I caught my reflection in the black phone screen. Big mistake. My cheeks looked tight. My forehead was doing this weird flaky thing. I’d just washed my face with that blue cleanser I got on sale, the one that smells like a hospital. My skin felt… loud. Squeaky. And not in a good way. I was staring at this little glass jar on my nightstand. A whipped tallow balm. Pear scent. Beef fat. For your face. I know. It sounds like something you’d find in a pioneer’s cabin, not on your skincare shelf. My friend sent it to me as a joke gift, I think. Or maybe she was serious. Anyway, the air in my apartment was so dry you could almost hear it. So I unscrewed the lid.

Here’s the thing about a daily skincare with tallow. You can’t just slap it on. At least, I don’t think you should. My routine’s a mess, but this part I do sort of right.

## How This Beef Tallow for Skin Thing Even Started

I didn’t wake up one day and think, “Ah yes, rendered cow fat, the secret to beauty.” No way. It was more like desperation. Last month, after a flight back from visiting my sister, my skin just gave up. It was red. It was angry. My usual lotion, the fancy one in the silver bottle, just sat on top and made it look greasy. It felt like my skin was thirsty but the water was locked away. I remembered this jar. The label said it was whipped beef tallow balm from grass-fed cows. Made in France. I guess the French know their fats. The logic, which I read while half-asleep one night, is that it mimics human skin sebum. So it gets absorbed deep, doesn’t just coat you. For chapped lips, sensitive skin, stuff like eczema. My skin isn’t diagnosed with anything, it’s just… sensitive to being alive in winter, apparently.

So one night, after my shower, I tried it. I was skeptical. Obviously. I mean, come on.

## What My Tallow Balm Routine Actually Looks Like

Okay so it’s usually at night. Like 10:30 PM. I’m in sweatpants. The TV is on but I’m not watching it. My face is damp. Not wet, just… damp. From the shower or sometimes I just splash it. That’s key, I think. You need a little water there for it to grab onto.

I scoop out a tiny bit. The size of a pea. Maybe a little less. It’s solid in the jar but soft, like cold butter. You rub it between your fingers for like two seconds and it melts. Totally melts. Then I just press it into my skin. My cheeks first, then forehead, chin. I don’t rub it in hard. Just press and pat. It feels… I don’t know. Different. Not slick. Not oily. It just sort of vanishes. My skin drinks it. It doesn’t feel like I’ve put anything on, which is the weirdest part. It feels calm. Quiet.

The smell is pear. But not like a Jolly Rancher. Not like a candle. It’s soft. A little sweet, but clean. Like you walked past a fruit bowl in a really clean kitchen. It’s not strong. It’s just there for a minute and then it’s gone. It’s nice. It doesn’t smell like beef. At all. Which, thank god.

Sometimes I use it in the morning. If I wake up and my face feels tight from the dry heater air. I’ll use an even smaller amount, just on the super dry patches. It sits under my sunscreen just fine. Doesn’t pill. Doesn’t do anything weird.

Oh, and my lips. I keep the jar by my bed. Before I turn the light off, I’ll dip a finger in and put the tiniest bit on my lips. It’s the best lip balm I’ve ever used. No joke. It just… fixes them. No more peeling. It’s magic.

Wait, my cat just jumped on the keyboard. brb.

Anyway. So yeah, that’s how to use tallow balm, I guess. Damp skin, tiny amount, press don’t rub. It’s not complicated. I used to have a 12-step routine. Serums, potions, acids. This feels stupidly simple in comparison.

## Why This Stuff Actually Works (I Think)

I’m not a scientist. But I’ve been using this pear tallow balm for a few weeks now. My skin isn’t “glowing” in that Instagram way. It’s just… normal. It doesn’t hurt. It doesn’t feel tight an hour after I wash it. The flaky patches on my forehead are gone. My cheeks aren’t red and pissed off all the time. It just feels like skin. Healthy, quiet skin. I didn’t expect that.

I think the sebum-mimicking thing is real. It feels like it’s working with my skin, not against it. Like it’s giving it back what the winter air and harsh cleansers steal away. It’s deeply hydrating but in a way that doesn’t feel heavy or cloggy. My face just feels balanced. It’s a weird thing to be excited about, but I am. I’m on my second jar now. I got it from this little Etsy shop my friend told me about. The owner was super nice when I had a question.

It’s become this non-negotiable part of my night. Like brushing my teeth. Wash face, maybe use a toner if I remember, tallow balm, done. It takes 60 seconds. My skin has never been lower maintenance. In winter! That’s the crazy part.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, I think so. It sounds gross but it’s not. It’s just fat. And since it’s similar to the oils our skin makes naturally, it absorbs really well. It doesn’t just sit on top and clog stuff up. It’s like giving your skin a food it recognizes.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Hasn’t for me. And my skin can get cloggy. Because it absorbs so deeply and isn’t just a surface layer of grease, I think it’s actually less likely to cause problems. My pores look fine. Better than fine.

**What does the pear tallow balm smell like?**
It’s fresh. Like a ripe pear but without the sugary sweetness. It’s light. It’s not a perfume-y smell, it’s just a gentle, clean fruit scent that fades fast. It’s really pleasant. Not overpowering at all.

So yeah. That’s my tallow balm routine. It’s simple. It works. My skin is happy for the first time in a winter maybe ever. I don’t know what else to say about it. If your skin is feeling angry and tight and nothing else is helping, it might be worth a shot. It was for me. I’m probably gonna order another jar soon. Just in case.
